prior_works.title: Geometric Lower Bounds for Distributed Parameter Estimation under Communication Constraints
prior_works.authors: Yanjun Han, Ayfer Özgür, Tsachy Weissman
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides a geometric/SDPI-based framework to convert bit constraints into minimax risk lower bounds, directly underpinning the paper’s optimality proofs across ℓ^p regimes and clarifying where elbows in rates can arise.

prior_works.title: Strong Data-Processing Inequalities for Channels and Bayesian Networks
prior_works.role: Core information-theoretic tool for lower bounds
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies strong data-processing inequalities that are routinely used to derive communication-constrained statistical lower bounds; the paper leverages this toolkit to certify optimality of its refinement protocols.

prior_works.title: Communication-Efficient Distributed Estimation of Discrete Distributions
prior_works.authors: Jayadev Acharya, Ziteng Sun, Huanyu Zhang
prior_works.role: Protocol design for discrete distribution estimation with limited bits
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces hashing/thresholding-based blackboard/user protocols for multinomial estimation under bit budgets, directly inspiring the paper’s use of random hashing, sample compression, and regime-splitting within its refinement framework.

prior_works.title: Successive Refinement of Information
prior_works.authors: Cory J. Effros (Equitz), Thomas M. Cover
prior_works.role: Foundational source coding concept enabling coarse-to-fine communication
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the principle of progressive descriptions that the paper adapts to estimation—first sending a coarse sketch, then refining messages guided by the rough estimate to meet minimax rates in different ℓ^p regimes.

prior_works.title: The Space Complexity of Approximating Frequency Moments
prior_works.authors: Noga Alon, Yossi Matias, Mario Szegedy
prior_works.role: Sketching and random hashing foundations for frequency estimation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the classical hashing/sketching paradigm for compressing frequency information, which the paper repurposes as random hashing and sample-compression primitives in its communication-limited distribution estimators.

prior_works.title: Minimax Estimation of Functionals of Discrete Distributions
prior_works.authors: Jiantao Jiao, Kartik Venkat, Yanjun Han, Tsachy Weissman
prior_works.role: Regime-dependent estimator design and thresholding for discrete distributions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Develops bias-variance tradeoffs and thresholding strategies across rare/common symbol regimes; these ideas inform the paper’s customized thresholding within the refinement pipeline and its analysis across ℓ^p losses.

synthesis_narrative: The paper targets the minimax characterization of communication-constrained distributed estimation of multinomial distributions under ℓ^p losses and devises refinement-based protocols that achieve the optimal rates across regimes, revealing an elbow at p = 2. Its lower-bound machinery is rooted in strong data-processing inequalities and geometric arguments for distributed estimation (Polyanskiy–Wu; Han–Özgür–Weissman), which translate bit budgets into quantitative limits on achievable risk. On the algorithmic side, the protocol architecture follows a coarse-to-fine blueprint inspired by successive refinement in source coding (Equitz–Cover): an initial sketch yields a rough estimate that adaptively guides later, more targeted communication. Concrete primitives for compressing distributional information—random hashing and sketching—trace to the streaming/sketching literature (Alon–Matias–Szegedy) and to communication-efficient protocols tailored for discrete distributions (Acharya–Sun–Zhang), which demonstrate how heavy hitters, hashing, and public randomness can be orchestrated under tight bit budgets. Finally, regime-aware estimation and thresholding techniques from functional estimation of discrete distributions (Jiao–Venkat–Han–Weissman) inform how the protocol treats heavy versus rare symbols and balance bias-variance across ℓ^p risks, helping to explain and attain the distinct rates on either side of p = 2. Together, these works directly enable the paper’s refinement methods, customized tools (successive refinement, sample compression, thresholding, hashing), and matching lower bounds that establish near-complete minimax optimality.
